contents.context:
With the help of robots, more than one-hundred-70 high school students in the Philippines were able to attend their graduation ceremony remotely.
The Senator Renato Cayetano Memorial Science and Technology High School in Manila found a way for its students to attend their graduation ceremony virtuallyby using robots to project the graduates' faces in real time.
The unique occasion came as the school had been seeking ways to push through with the once-in-a-life-time event, despite most ceremonies being cancelled in the country due to COVID-19.

"It's a very momentous event that you won't want to miss and we would like to make sure that our students will not miss it despite the COVID-19 pandemic."

Meanwhile, over in the U.S., the Faith Lutheran High School in Las Vegas went a different route, and decided to hold its graduation ceremony at a racetrack.
Wearing gowns, more than two-hundred-50 graduates rode in cars with their families and listened to the graduation address on the radio.
After receiving their diplomas through the window, the students took a victory lap around the Las Vegas Motor Speedway racetrack.

Students say it was unexpected and that it will be an unforgettable graduation.

"With the difficulties going on I was bummed because I didn't think we'd have a graduation this school year, and that's something every student looks forward to."

"We were worried for a while it was going to be postponed or online. But I feel like this was a very cool substitution."

The school's CEO, said that the special graduation sought to recognize the efforts of the students and to give them a memorable graduation experience in spite of the ongoing pandemic.

Kim Mok-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : mokyeon90@gmail.com
contents.headline:
Schools across the globe hold unique social distancing graduation ceremonies amid COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-27 17:08:37 KST

contents.context:
Beijing is set to vote on the new Hong Kong national security law it proposed at China's National People's Congress on Thursday, and it's almost certain that it will be passed by the highly choreographed parliament.
The new national security law will allow Beijing to implement measures that prevent and punish subversion, terrorism, separatism and foreign interference in Hong Kong.
If enacted, it will mark the first time that a Chinese law carrying criminal penalties has been introduced into Hong Kong's legal code, bypassing the territory's legislature and public consultation processes and is likely to further strain Washington-Beijing relations.
Reporter : yoohong@arirang.com
contents.headline:
China's National People's Congress to vote on Hong Kong security law on Thurs.
Updated: 2020-05-27 17:08:00 KST

contents.context:
Foreign media outlets are once again praising South Korea's rapid response to the COVID-19 pandemic, along with its efforts to prevent potential infections in schools.
U.S. newspaper, the Washington Post hailed South Korea's preparation in reopening schools, saying that "the pictures say it all."
The photos in the articles show Korean students having lunch with clear partitions separating them, and a classroom where each student is sitting at an isolated desk wearing a mask.
In one elementary school, a special kit, containing a mask and hand sanitizer, was prepared for students.
The Washington Post's article said the photos show the efforts Korea was making to prevent students and teachers from contracting the virus.
And it's not just the media that are praising Korea's response. A report from Pew Research found the U.S. public highly rated how South Korea had tackled the outbreak.
In the survey of around 11-thousand U.S. adults, 66-percent said Korea has done either a good or excellent job in dealing with the outbreak.
This is a higher rating than they gave their own country, in which more than half said the U.S. has done either only a fair or a poor job.
They also gave China a low rating, with more than 37-percent saying Beijing's countermeasures were poorly done.
In a report on the research, the BBC described it as "praise for South Korea, criticism for China."
The British media outlet added that South Korea's ability to promptly react to the COVID-19 outbreak has made the country a global role model.
So far, South Korea has kept the number of new cases below 50 since April 9th, with the death toll standing at 269.
Kim Sung-min, Arirang News
Reporter : smkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Foreign media outlets praise S. Korea's preparation for school semester, response to COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-27 17:03:14 KST

contents.context:
The World Health Organization says it expects (HIGH-DROXY-CHLORO-QUINN) hydroxychloroquine safety results is be out by mid-June, after safety concerns prompted a group to end its large trial on COVID-19 patients.
The WHO previously called time on the drug use in its multi-national trial called Solidarity-- after a study published in a British medical journal suggested the drug had increased mortality rates and caused irregular heartbeats.
U.S. President Donald Trump--- who once pushed the drug as a COVID-19 treatment -- said he's no longer taking it after completing a two-week course of the malaria drug.
Reporter : ashin@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
Hydroxychloroquine safety findings for COVID-19 out by mid-June: WHO
Updated: 2020-05-27 10:03:24 KST

contents.context:
A mink with COVID-19 has infected two people in the Netherlands, in what is probably the first such transmission case since the outbreak started.
The country's agriculture minister said Tuesday that mink carrying the virus were found on four of the 155 farms in the Netherlands.
The minister said animal-to-human transmission outside the farm was "negligible."
The source of infection has been shown to be a sick human.
The nation's health authorities said the mink-to-human transmissions were practically unheard of, although the original source of infection in China was very likely animals.
Reporter : yoonjm@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Mink infected two humans with COVID-19 in Netherlands
Updated: 2020-05-27 09:53:33 KST

contents.context:
Last week, Beijing introduced a draft national security law that will bypass the legislature in Hong Kong, prohibiting any act of treason, secession, sedition and subversion against the Chinese government.
Despite the massive protest launched last Sunday by a pro-democracy group in Hong Kong, the bill is set to get the green light on Thursday.
According to Bernard Chan, deputy to China's National People's Congress, the Chinese central government is introducing the law in Hong Kong because the territory's authorities have not been able to do it locally for over 20 years, calling it a "failure".
The Hong Kong government is required to draft a national security law in accordance with Article 23 of the territory's mini constitution known as the Basic Law, but it has not been able to, as a previous attempt in 2003 was shelved after mass protests.
According to Chan, Beijing feels an urgency to introduce the law after the now scrapped extradition bill led to massive unrest in Hong Kong.
While the introduction of the law on Thursday will almost certainly lead to further unrest in Hong Kong, Chan says Hong Kong does not have a say in whether it wants a national security law or not.
Washington is continuing to express concerns over the law, as White House economic adviser Larry Kudlow on Tuesday said China was making a "big mistake", and pledged Washington would pay the expenses of U.S. firms that want to shift operations from Hong Kong or China.
President Trump also expressed displeasure over the law, and says he finds it hard to see "how Hong Kong can remain a financial hub if China takes over."
Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam, however, says other countries "have no place" interfering, as she defended the law, calling it a "responsible" move to protect Hong Kong's law-abiding majority.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
China to pass national security law on Thursday despite opposition in Hong Kong
Updated: 2020-05-27 09:52:34 KST

contents.context:
An elderly South Korean woman who speaks no English at all has written 138 letters in English to send to Ethiopian war veterans.
On hearing that South Korea plans to send masks to Ethiopian veterans of the Korean War, Choi Sam-ja, from Chilgok county, Gyeongsangbuk-do Province, decided to write letters to the 138 veterans still alive.
She wrote that South Koreans will never forget their commitment and expressed her gratitude for what they did.
After first writing the letter in Korean, she had it translated into English, and later handwrote 138 letters.
Over 6-thousand Ethiopian soldiers fought in the Korean War.
Choi's letters and masks are to be delivered to the war veterans early next month.
Reporter : jhlucyoh@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Elderly S. Korean woman writes letters to 138 Ethiopian war veterans
Updated: 2020-05-26 17:04:19 KST

contents.context:
U.S. President Donald Trump has warned China that Washington would react "very strongly" after a Chinese official said Beijing is set to impose new national security legislation on Hong Kong after last year's pro-democracy unrest.
The White House National Security Adviser Robert O'Brien added if China's national security legislation for the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region is enacted, the United States would likely impose sanctions on China.

"I don't know what it is because nobody knows yet. If it happens, we'll address that issue very strongly."

"Hong Kong is China's Hong Kong and the Hong Kong affairs are purely China's internal affairs. What legislation the HKSAR introduces and how and when it enacts the legislation is entirely within the scope of China's sovereignty. The U.S. has no right to criticize or interfere. If the U.S. is bent on harming China's interests, China will have to take all necessary measures to fight back."

Rising tensions between the world's two superpowers, U.S. and China coming under the spotlight in the wake of the latest protests in Hong Kong.
It's the topic of our News In-depth with Mason Richey, Associate Professor of International Politics at Hankuk University of Foreign Studies live in the studio with me..

Over the weekend, thousands of Hong Kongers took to the streets to oppose the China's move to go around Hong Kong's own legislature and draft measures against secession, foreign influence and terrorism. What are Hong Kongers protesting about exactly?

With his plan to impose sweeping antisedition legislation on Hong Kong, Chinese leader Xi Jinping has revealed a willingness to alter the onetime British colony's special status as a self-governing city with a speed and scope that has surprised many, from pro-democracy activists to diplomats to businesspeople.
What does this move suggest about Xi's shift in his approach to Hong Kong? What is Xi Jinping attempting to do ultimately?

The U.S. has said it would slap China with sanctions should Beijing move ahead with the implementation of this law. What does China's such move mean for the U.S., really?

For many months, China watchers have been they were not overruling the Hong Kong authorities. Now, they are cracking down. It feels like U.S. President Donald Trump has been praising Xi when he wanted the trade deal and now the gloves have come off as he's campaigning.
What do you make of this downward spiral and how dangerous is it for the rest of the world as tensions brew between the world's two superpowers?

Amid this global pandemic, China has foregone their customary growth target, which they've set every year since 1994. Every year, they've achieved that target, and often, a fair bit more.
Friday, Chinese Premier Li announced that they have not set a specific target for economic growth.
An indicator of great uncertainty, why have they not set a growth target, and what does it mean for the world's second-largest economy?

Rising tensions between the United States and China are spilling over into the airline industry.
Washington has accused Beijing of blocking American carriers from resuming flights to China, prompting U.S. authorities to more heavily scrutinize Chinese airlines.
What can you tell us about this?

China is also demanding that the U.S. withdraw sanctions on tech suppliers. So, the spillover effect from the U.S., China tensions is rather extensive. Is the world ready for for the two superpowers to go head to head?

What is your forecast on the Hong Kong issue? How do you foresee things to unfold on that front between the U.S. and China?

Mason Richey, Associate Professor of International Politics at Hankuk University of Foreign Studies, many thanks as always for your insights. We appreciate i
Reporter : jenmoon@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
U.S., China Brewing Tensions Over Hong Kong: Global Implications
Updated: 2020-05-26 15:17:33 KST

contents.context:
China's central bank has lowered its official yuan midpoint to its weakest level since the 2008 global financial crisis.
Reuters reports the People's Bank of China on Monday set the midpoint at around 7.1-2-0-9 yuan per U.S. dollar prior to the market open.
That's point-38 percent lower than the previous fix of 7.0-9-3-9..
Beijing's move hints at yet another showdown between the U.S. and China, as bilateral relations between the world's two superpowers have deteriorated over COVID-19 and China's proposed new national security law for Hong Kong.
But analysts stress it's too early to assume this signals the start of a currency war between Washington and Beijing.
Reuters says China's move merely reflects losses in the spot yuan.
In fact, the offshore Chinese yuan hit a two-month low of 7.1-6-4-4 against the greenback last Friday following Beijing's new law proposalas investors flocked to the dollar, a traditional safe-haven.
Having the yuan's daily reference rate above 7 a dollar is considered the Maginot line for China.
In fact, Beijing set the rate below 7 yuan a dollar when the U.S. and China reached their phase one trade deal earlier this year.
As a result of the COVID-19 pandemic, China is targeting a 2020 budget deficit of at least 3.6 percent of GDP, well above last year's 2.8 percent.
Despite active financial measures taken by China to boost its sluggish economy during the pandemic, analysts' concerns linger over Beijing's financial woes.
Kim Dami, Arirang News.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
China lowers yuan midpoint to weakest since 2008 global financial crisis
Updated: 2020-05-26 13:22:17 KST

contents.context:
The World Health Organization has suspended its trial of (HIGH-DROXY-CLAWO-QUINN) hydroxychloroquine as a treatment for COVID-19 due to safety concerns.
WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus said Monday that the concern relates to the use of the drug to tackle COVID-19.
However, he noted the drug is generally safe to use in patients with autoimmune diseases or malaria.
(HIGH-DROXY-CLAWO-QUINN) Hydroxychloroquine, what U.S. President Donald Trump has praised as a panacea for COVID-19, is an anti-malarial drug to treat illnesses including lupusbut not proven to treat COVID-19.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
WHO suspends trial of hydroxychloroquine as COVID-19 treatment over safety concerns
Updated: 2020-05-26 10:03:41 KST

contents.context:
On Sunday, thousands of citizens took to the streets of Hong Kong in response to China's plans to pass its national security law, prohibiting any act of treason, secession, sedition, and subversion against the Chinese government.
The protest led to roughly two hundred arrests and left many injured, as police fired tear gas and water cannon on protesters.
With China set to pass the law on Thursday, protesters are digging in for a fight.

"A lot of people think that we exploited their freedom when coming out to protest, but I think the national security law will affect our freedom in the future and the freedom of our next generation. If our generation don't come out to fight (for freedom), it won't exist any more for the next generation."

However, there's a minority of the population that agree with Beijing's decision to pass the law.

"As Hong Kong has no capability or method to enact (their own national security law), I don't object the Chinese Central government to enact the national security law decisively and I agree with that."

However, the vast majority of Hong Kong citizens believe that once the law is passed, Hong Kong's autonomy and freedom will end.
Which is why Joshua Wong, the figure behind the pro-democracy movement has called for international support through an op-ed in the Washington Post.
Along with Washington's opposition to the passing of the law, Taiwanese president Tsai Ing-wen says her country will provide the people of Hong Kong with "necessary assistance".
Taiwan has become a refuge for a growing number of pro-democracy protesters who have fled Hong Kong, as it has no law on refugees who seek asylum on the island.
In addition, Taiwan's laws promise help for Hong Kong citizens whose safety and liberty are threatened for political reasons.
While the protests in Hong Kong have won widespread sympathy in Taiwan, and the support from President Tsai, her administration's already poor ties with Beijing are rapidly eroding even further.
Meanwhile, the EU Foreign Affairs Chief Josep Borrell has also called on China to respect Hong Kong's autonomy and the "one country, two systems" principle. He noted that a more 'robust' strategy toward China is needed, amid signs Asia is replacing the U.S. as the center of global power.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
China to pass national security law on Thursday; Hong Kong protesters appeal for international support
Updated: 2020-05-26 10:00:58 KST

contents.context:
Countries in Europe are easing coronavirus restrictions, with the UK rolling out plans for more easing of its lockdown.
British Prime Minister Boris Johnson said during a regular press briefing on Monday that the country is set to reopen thousands of high street shops, department stores and shopping centers from June.
He explained that outdoor markets could be reopened first, followed by all other non-essential retail from mid-June.

"Today I want to give the retail sector notice of our intentions to reopen shops so they too can get ready. So I can announce that it is our intention to allow outdoor markets to reopen from June 1st, subject to all premises being made COVID-secure, as well as car showrooms which often have significant outdoor space and where it is generally easier to apply social distancing."

Similar measures are being put in place in Spain as well.
In Barcelona and Madrid, residents can now meet in groups of up to ten people in their homes or on the terraces of bars and restaurants.
Starting Monday, restrictions were also eased at beaches, following ten weeks of an intense lockdown.

"I feel happy because I was able to go out and feel the freedom to do it. It's all about first times today. First time we eat paella. First time we drink a glass of wine. It makes me happy, because I love the sea. I love to eat by the sea. I am very happy."

Nevertheless, in some countries like Germany and Italy, lockdown easing has led to new cluster infections, complicating their efforts to reopen their economies.
In Germany, more than 100 people were found to have been infected following a Baptist church service in Frankfurt, while over a dozen others tested positive after attending the opening of a restaurant in the northern town of Leer.
Italy will be mobilizing nearly 70-thousand volunteers to enforce social distancing rules, amid fears of a possible second wave.
While they do not have any policing powers, they will patrol parks, markets and bar areas where there could be large gatherings following the partial easing of the national lockdown.
Kim Hyo-sun, Arirang News.
Reporter : hyosunee88@gmail.com
contents.headline:
European countries like UK, Spain set to ease COVID-19 restrictions, following weeks of continued lockdown
Updated: 2020-05-26 10:00:57 KST
